item.title: Dequeue
item.description: This is basically a [[/notes/Queue|Queue]] data structure, except the user has access to both the head and the tail.

item.title: Dynamic Arrays
item.description: Normally, adding an element to an already full [[/notes/Array|Array]] would take $O(n)$ time, if you resize it by 1 cell everytime an element is added, that is.

item.title: Array
item.description: Arrays are data structures that allow access to its entries using indexes. They are basically an amount of space allocated in memory, and each entry in the array is placed in that space one after another.

item.title: Circularly Linked List
item.description: This is another type of specialized [[/notes/Linked List|Linked List]]. Normally in a linked list, the tail node would have the next pointer set as null.

item.title: Copying Lists
item.description: When copying lists, you need to create a new [[/notes/Array|Array]]/[[/notes/Linked List|Linked List]] and copy over each element from the original list into the new one.

item.title: Doubly Linked List
item.description: Doubly linked list are very similar to [[/notes/Linked List|Linked List]] except that instead of having one pointer at each node, which points to the next node, each node has two pointers: one pointing to the next node and the other pointing to the previous node.
